issues.title: Scope/Goal/Intended Use (from Italo)
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
> Hi Med, WG(s),
> 
> I think the document needs some important updates, however I do support the adoption of the draft as a WG document
> 
> The work is in the scope of NMOP WG (as explicitly stated in the charter) and I agree that NMOP WG needs to develop a common view of the definitions, use cases and requirements for digital map, which is what this I-D is aiming for
> 
> I wished to provide more constructive and detailed comments to the draft, but I am running out of time for the adoption call so I am starting to share an high-level overview my major comments. At this moment in time, it is not fully clear to me whether the digital map is intended to be:
> 
> •	aimed at supporting the full lifecycle of network management/control (as it seems to me being stated in the draft) or just the network visualization application (as I have understood from previous discussions and PoCs)
> 
> •	addressing only network scenarios with L2&L3 technologies (as I have understood from previous discussions) or any network scenarios where TE layers, such as WDM, OTN or MPLS-TE, are also present (as I would assume by reading the draft as technology-agnostic)
> 
> •	addressing only the applicability of topology models in support of digital twins (as it seems to me being stated in the draft) or more than just topology (as I have understood from previous discussions)
> 
> IMHO, the NMOP WG should take on this draft and improve it to clarify all the points as well as other doubts I have seen from other comments sent to the list(s) as replies to this WG adoption call
> 
> Italo

issues.title: Is topology definition needed
issues.author: OlgaHuawei
issues.body:
There were multiple comments about the topology definition and Olga's statement at IETF120 that we ere not able to ind terminology definition in IETF:

Adrian: 
        This surprised me, but even mapping this to: there is no definition of "network topology" she appears to be right.
        The best I could find was in RFC 7399, but that is still woolly.
        Looking back and back and back, the concept of a topology of a network seems to predate the RFC series. 
        Wikipedia seems to be fairly accurate, but not completely concise.
        So, my conclusion, adding a definition will be helpful.
        But, it might need to be scoped to the work for fear that you are redefining a term widely used in many previous RFCs.

Pedro:
        A redefinition can be a bit controversial. If there is any concept or nuance not included in the definition of "network topology" 
        as derived from the basic (dictionary?) definitions of "network" and "topology", it should be denoted in the name and not by 
        redefining the term. Otherwise, it is fair to "recall" other sources but no more than that.

Dan:
        Section 2 of RFC7399 is what I though digital map definition was - augmented by nodes relationships, LSDB basically.  
        What should be added for digital map definition ?

Adrian:
          We wrote 7399 partly because there were some ambiguities in the TE world. Funnily (?) we failed to address the 
          issue of a  definition for "topology" in 9522.
          Places I might have hoped to see topology defined include 5212, 5440, 5693, 7926, and 9552. But, sadly not.
          I suppose my concern is that 7399 defines "topology" only by an indirection through the definition of "TED".
          Anything we do in NMOP should certainly be compatible with that text, and ideally not perturbate the many RFCs 
          that use the  term "network topology". But a short, precise definition 
          (perhaps together with a pointer to 7399) might be helpful.

issues.author: OlgaHuawei

comments.author: nigel-r-davis
comments.body:
@OlgaHuawei Just a few thoughts...

We need to be careful with the term "layer", there are various granularities (e.g., marketing layers L0, L1, L2 etc. technology layer ODU, Ethernet etc. OSI layers: Transport, network... ), a layer at one granularity is multiple layers at another. We also found it challenging separating network partitioning,

In TAPI we concluded that several technology layers could be grouped into a single toplology (hence multi-layer). There are degrees of this, some very obvious and some not so.

When you get IP over IP, this can be considered as one layer because of technology or several because of partitioning.

This may lead us to viewpoint, where from one viewpoint it is a single layer whereas from another it is multople layers.

issues.author: OlgaHuawei
issues.body:
draft-ietf-nmop-digital-map-concept
The following are sample use cases that require Digital Map:
* Service-> subservice -> resource
* Resource -> subservice -> service
But the terms service, subservice, and resource are not defined.


== Advice from Adrian==
Consider defining "service" and "subservice" in
draft-ietf-nmop-digital-map-concept, and importing "resource" from
draft-ietf-nmop-terminology.
Resource: A component, commodity, service, or capability that can be
used to support the delivery of some function.

comments.author: OlgaHuawei
comments.body:
Updated in the draft as follow, to be reviewed by others:

Service:
: Represents network connectivity service provided over a network that enables devices, systems, or networks to
communicate and exchange data with each other. It provides the underlying infrastructure and mechanisms
necessary for establishing, maintaining, and managing connections between different endpoints.
The example services are: L2VPN, L3VPN, EVPN, VPLS, VPWS,

Subservice:
: Represents component of the service that can be independently managed but is not provided as a service.
The example subservices are: MPLS Tunnels, SRV6 Tunnels, VRFs, VPN Links, IGP Links.

Resource:
: Defined in {{?I-D.ietf-nmop-terminology}}

issues.title: Navigation across the abstraction levels inside a single network layer (Italo)
issues.author: OlgaHuawei
issues.body:
Italo: 

My point is that in a multi-layer network you need to navigate across layers, but also in case of a single layer, it is possible to define multiple abstraction levels (as defined in RFC8795) and then there is a need to navigate across multiple abstraction levels

I am  not sure my comment at the mike today about topology abstraction has been fully understood

If you are not fully familiar with the concept of topology abstraction, I would suggest the following background reading for the definition of topology abstraction:

  *   RFC 8453 (in particular section 5)
  *   RFC 8795 (and in particular sections 3.13, 4.1 and 4.4)
  *   draft-ietf-teas-te-topo-and-tunnel-modeling (in particular section 1.3)

In a nutshell a network (even a single-layer network) can be represented in multiple ways providing different abstraction view of the same network. In such a case, it would be beneficial being able to navigate among the different level of abstractions (e.g., to understand which set of nodes in the native topology are actually represented as a single node in an abstract topology being built on top of the native topology).

This navigation is different and orthogonal to the multi-layer navigation where for example we need to report which L2 path is supporting a given L3 node

My question is therefore: is SIMAP only dealing with native topologies and navigation among the different networking layers (L3, L2, optical, ...) or also dealing with abstract topologies and navigation among the different level of abstraction?

comments.author: OlgaHuawei
comments.body: I think there is no need to have different basic topology models for abstract and native topologies. But we need to be driven by use cases, so we should discuss with operators. If there is a use case that requires both native and abstract topologies and relations between them, we should add a new requirement for SIMAP to be able to model both abstract and native topologies and layers between them.

issues.title: termination point vs interface
issues.author: oscargdd
issues.body:
The topology model (RFC 8345) is based on termination points NOT interfaces.

However, throught the document we mix both.... 

I believe SIMAP could be the place to clarify the relationship between both.

comments.author: OlgaHuawei
comments.body:
Well spotted - we really do that. The RFC8345 models it in a generic way via termination points and these can be interfaces. But termination points can be other entities as well.

We have interface in the requirements as this is the most common example of termination point, and the terminology that operators use. And in most of the cases tps are related to interfaces or sub interfaces at different levels. But I think we can potentially have TPs abstracted without having interface there, for example in the SRv6 initial PoC we proposed to use SIDs as termination points. We will review during the hackathon if there is better approach.

Some quotes from RFC8345:
   A node has a list of termination points that are used to terminate
   links.  An example of a termination point might be a physical or
   logical port or, more generally, an interface.

   Termination points can ultimately be mapped to interfaces.

comments.author: OlgaHuawei
comments.body:
I updated the draft, just changed interface to termination point. There is already some clarification in RFC8345 about the relation, so I did not add it here. 
I suggest we close

comments.author: nigel-r-davis
comments.body:
@OlgaHuawei @oscargdd 
I think, at this stage, only using termination point in the draft is correct. But I think there are still challenges with the two concepts. I see in RFC8345 there are statements, but I find them ambiguous. For example " An example of a termination point might be a physical or logical port or, more generally, an interface.". I think we need to be much clearer here. 

Physical should be something that has spatial dimensions. A termination point never has. It can be an abstraction that always represents some logical view. 

I also think that an interface as defined in other RFCs has a different definition to termination point in RFC8345. This relates to the challenge we had recently on whether termination should represent the same concept as the ONF/ITU-T LTP (G.7711) and hence could be specialized to both TAPI NEP (Link End) and TAPI CEP (termination functions) or just the TAPI NEP. 

If the latter, then the generalized representation of generalized function is missing in IETF. If it is both NEP and CEP etc. then it could be quite similar to the full ONF LTP (which is a multi-layer full functionality representation of termination which can take a variety of subset forms including the CEP and the NEP forms) although more skeletal. We could argue that this then represents the skeleton of an interface which is a multi-layer, multi-function termination capability (where there is a restriction as to which subsets are allowed). 

We found in ONF and ITU-T that it was vital to clarify this. We need to be clear on this. I have previously engaged in this challenge and we were successful in clarifying. I could take a shot here if other think beneficial.

comments.body:
@OlgaHuawei Thanks. I will prepare some text and get feedback through thee NMOP mailing as you suggest.

De : Olga Havel [<olga.havel@huawei.com>](mailto:olga.havel@huawei.com) 
Envoyé : mercredi 4 décembre 2024 12:11
À : BOUCADAIR Mohamed INNOV/NET [<mohamed.boucadair@orange.com>](mailto:mohamed.boucadair@orange.com); [nmop@ietf.org](mailto:nmop@ietf.org)
Objet : RE: SIMAP: REQ-LAYER-NAVIGATE vs REQ-RELATIONSHIPS
 
Hi Med,
 
The current requirements were split into 3 groups:
1.	Core requirements – collected requirements from the operators, they are really functional requirements based on the operator input 
2.	Design requirements – requirements derived from the core requirements, that are the requirements for how to design the YANG module and SIMAP API. These are functional requirements translated into the requirements for the model designer. The reason for doing this is to ensure that the YANG module is designed according to the core requirements, and that it could be used for both design and review of the proposed YANG module. I agree there is some duplication and we at one interim meeting did mention to remove REQ-RELATIONSHIP. I suggest to change the REQ-LAYER-NAVIGATE description to: SIMAP must provide capability to navigate inside the topology layer and between the topology layers. That would translate into REQ-RELATIONSHIP and some other. 
 
1.	The following is the quote from the draft: 
The following are design requirements for modelling the SIMAP.  Theey
are derived from the core requerements collected from the operators
                                                      and although there is some duplication, these are focused on
                                                    summarizing the requirements for the design of the model and API:
 
3.	Architecture requirements – it was added as some operators were mentioning performance, scale and network discovery – which are really not requirements for the YANG module and API itself, they are more requirements on the controller that provides the SIMAP API. They are commons sense requirements for any controller, therefore I am not sure if we want to keep them here as well. 
 
We can discuss if we need to keep the different categories of requirements as this or merge them. I personally think that it can be useful to have the functional requirements as collected from the operators and design requirements (or  model requirements) derived specifically for how the model the SIMAP YANG.
 
There may be some missing, we need to see if we want to add the ones we found during the PoC as gaps to the design requirements (bdir, mtptp, cross-domain, etc).
 
Best regards,
Olga

issues.title: REQ-SEMANTIC
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
From @graf3net:

From a network operators requirements perspective, I think the requirements list is pretty much complete. 

I only have one comment:

REQ-SEMANTIC:
SIMAP must provide semantics for layered network topologies and for linking external models/data.

I think we need to expand or add additional requirements to ensure that the following is covered:

•	Provider data plane (Flow) needs to be correlatable to underlay and customer data plane to overlay topology 
•	Underlay control plane routing state needs to be correlatable to underlay L3 topology. Overlay control-plane routing state needs to be correlate-able to overlay L3 network topology 

As an example:

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7011#section-8

   If an Information Element is required more than once in a Template,
   the different occurrences of this Information Element SHOULD follow
   the logical order of their treatments by the Metering Process.  For
   example, if a selected packet goes through two hash functions, and if
   the two hash values are sent within a single Template, the first
   occurrence of the hash value should belong to the first hash function
   in the Metering Process.  For example, when exporting the two source
   IP addresses of an IPv4-in-IPv4 packet, the first sourceIPv4Address
   Information Element occurrence should be the IPv4 address of the
   outer header, while the second occurrence should be the address of
   the inner header.  Collecting Processes MUST properly handle
   Templates with multiple identical Information Elements.


In a SRv6 enabled network, sourceIPv6Address appears in a IPFIX data-template/data-record for a captured flow on a SRv6 enabled provider interface twice. Once in relation to provider data plane in the underlay, and once as relation to the customer data plane in the overlay.

SIMAP must provide the semantic capability that each sourceIPv6Address can be mapped to the overlay and underlay network topology. Both topologies might not be uniquely addressed, the VPN context (in SRv6 these are the SID's, https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8986#name-srv6-sid) needs to be considered therefore as well.

The same requirement also applies to the control plane. Taking BMP/BGP as an example. The BMP peer distinguisher (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7854#section-4.2) needs to be correlateable to the VRF of a node and the next-hop attribute of the NLRI in the BMP route-monitoring (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7854#section-4.6) encapsulated message to the underlay network topology while the path attribute of the NLRI in the BMP route-monitoring encapsulated message to the overlay topology.

I think REQ-SEMANTIC describes that requirement very high level, but I suggest to expand the description, maybe with examples I described to establish more clarity.

I agree with REQ-TOPO-ONLY that dynamic paths are outside of SIMAP scope. However as part of REQ-SEMANTIC, it lays the foundation to map it as external data.

I hope that makes sense.

Best wishes
Thomas
